6. Marcionis deus melior, i. e. not the Creator, the ‘just’ God, in Marcion’s system, hut the ‘deus solius bonitatis,' ch. 34. Marcion denied the uuity oi the First Principle, and postulated two ἀρχαί οι· ruling powers. These were a Suprema God oi pure benevolence who was unknown to man until revealed by Christ ; and a just or severe God, the Creator oi the visible universe, the God oi theold Testament. Comp. odo. a Stoicis. So again ch. 303 but the idea more nearly approaches the gods of Epicurus than of the Stoica: comp. Theoph. ad nus. ii. 4. Tertullian confusas the Stoica and Epicuream, Apol. 47. ‘De tran- quillitate,' however, is used here in contrast to the mundane activity oi the Creator, since Marcion’s ‘higher God’ neither concerned himself with mankind nor was known to them.
